text.content: Whose Opinions Do Language Models Reflect?

title.plain_text: Whose Opinions Do Language Models Reflect?

text.content: Introduction
Whose opinions (if any) do language models reflect?

rich_text.plain_text: Whose opinions (if any) do language models reflect?

text.content: A key evaluation for LMs in open-ended tasks will be not only to assess whether models are human-aligned broadly but also to identify whose opinions are reflected by LMs

rich_text.plain_text: A key evaluation for LMs in open-ended tasks will be not only to assess whether models are human-aligned broadly but also to identify whose opinions are reflected by LMs

text.content: Contribution of this paper
A framework to study the opinions reflected by LMs and their alignment with different human populations

rich_text.plain_text: A framework to study the opinions reflected by LMs and their alignment with different human populations

text.content: Build the OpinionQA dataset
Metrics
Representativeness: How aligned is the default LM opinion distribution with the general US population(or a demographic group)?

rich_text.plain_text: Representativeness: How aligned is the default LM opinion distribution with the general US population(or a demographic group)?

text.content: Steerability: Can an LM emulate the opinion distribution of a group when appropriately prompted?

rich_text.plain_text: Steerability: Can an LM emulate the opinion distribution of a group when appropriately prompted?

text.content: Consistency: Are the groups LMs align with consistent across the topic?

rich_text.plain_text: Consistency: Are the groups LMs align with consistent across the topic?

text.content: The OpinionQA Dataset
Three challenges to tackle
Identify topics where these opinions are relevant and curate pertinent questions for them

rich_text.plain_text: Identify topics where these opinions are relevant and curate pertinent questions for them

text.content: The questions must be designed such that we can easilty extract LM opinions on them

rich_text.plain_text: The questions must be designed such that we can easilty extract LM opinions on them

text.content: We need a reference distribution of human opinions from representative groups to compare LMs to

rich_text.plain_text: We need a reference distribution of human opinions from representative groups to compare LMs to

The primary approach for the latter currently is to use

text.content: public opinion surveys
These surveys address the first of the tree challenges with the help of experts, who identify topics of public interest and carefully design questions to capture nuances of the topic

text.content: Instantiation OpinionQA
We apply this methodology to the annual ‚ÄúAmerican Trends Panel‚Äù(ATP) polls conducted by Pew research to build the OpinionQA dataset.

rich_text.plain_text: We apply this methodology to the annual ‚ÄúAmerican Trends Panel‚Äù(ATP) polls conducted by Pew research to build the OpinionQA dataset.

text.content: This methodology is general, the OpinionQA dataset itself is English and US-centric. Thus, our subsequent analysis is limited to US populace.

rich_text.plain_text: This methodology is general, the OpinionQA dataset itself is English and US-centric. Thus, our subsequent analysis is limited to US populace.

text.content: Measuring human-LM alignment
Discuss how to probe language model opinions on questions from our OpinionQA dataset and compare them to the previously-obtained human opinion distributions

rich_text.plain_text: Discuss how to probe language model opinions on questions from our OpinionQA dataset and compare them to the previously-obtained human opinion distributions

text.content: Interfacing with models
Prompting the model
Due to the multiple-choice nature of samples in our dataset, we can use the standard prompting approaches used for traditional question answering tasks

rich_text.plain_text: Due to the multiple-choice nature of samples in our dataset, we can use the standard prompting approaches used for traditional question answering tasks

text.content: When evaluating representativeness, the goal is to understand the LM‚Äôs default opinion distribution, and we prompt the model using this standard QA template without any added context

rich_text.plain_text: When evaluating representativeness, the goal is to understand the LM‚Äôs default opinion distribution, and we prompt the model using this standard QA template without any added context

text.content: Measuring steerability involves testing the model‚Äôs ability to adapt to a particular group.

rich_text.plain_text: Measuring steerability involves testing the model‚Äôs ability to adapt to a particular group.

text.content: We consider three approaches to supply this information to the LM

rich_text.plain_text: We consider three approaches to supply this information to the LM

text.content: QA: The group information is provided as a response to a previous multiple-choice survey question, using the phrasing used by Pew to collect this information.

rich_text.plain_text: QA: The group information is provided as a response to a previous multiple-choice survey question, using the phrasing used by Pew to collect this information.

text.content: BIO: The group information is provided as a free-text response to a biographic question

rich_text.plain_text: BIO: The group information is provided as a free-text response to a biographic question

text.content: PORTRAY: The LM is instructed to pretend to be a member of said group, similar to the crowd-sourcing design.

rich_text.plain_text: PORTRAY: The LM is instructed to pretend to be a member of said group, similar to the crowd-sourcing design.

text.content: Robustness

: We ensure that all our subsequent results are robust to such design choices by replicating our analysis with different prompt templates, and permuting the order in which answer choices are presented to the model

text.content: Representativeness
The Metric
We define the representativeness of an Lm with respect to the overall population as the average alignment between default opinion distribution and the overall population

rich_text.plain_text: We define the representativeness of an Lm with respect to the overall population as the average alignment between default opinion distribution and the overall population

text.content: Are Current LMs representative?
Overall, we observe that none of the models are perfectly representative of the general populace.

rich_text.plain_text: Overall, we observe that none of the models are perfectly representative of the general populace.

text.content: Each of demographic groups is more representative of the overall populace than any of the LMs studied

rich_text.plain_text: Each of demographic groups is more representative of the overall populace than any of the LMs studied

text.content: for most models is comparable to the opinion alignment of agnostic and orthodox people on abortion or democrats and republicans on climate change

rich_text.plain_text: for most models is comparable to the opinion alignment of agnostic and orthodox people on abortion or democrats and republicans on climate change

text.content: Group representativeness
The group representativeness scores for all the base LMs share striking similarities and thus mimic similar pools of human writers

rich_text.plain_text: The group representativeness scores for all the base LMs share striking similarities and thus mimic similar pools of human writers

text.content: The opinions reflected by these models align more with people who are liberal, high income, well-educated, and not religious or belong to religions other than Buddhists, Muslims and Hindus.

rich_text.plain_text: The opinions reflected by these models align more with people who are liberal, high income, well-educated, and not religious or belong to religions other than Buddhists, Muslims and Hindus.

text.content: Model representativeness
Human-feedback tuned models are less representative of overall opinions.

rich_text.plain_text: Human-feedback tuned models are less representative of overall opinions.

text.content: Specifically, it has an extremely sharp opinion distribution for most questions.

rich_text.plain_text: Specifically, it has an extremely sharp opinion distribution for most questions.

text.content: Refusals
In our comparison of human and LM opinions so far, we omitted the ‚Äúrefusal‚Äù option for all question due to its non-ordinal nature.

rich_text.plain_text: In our comparison of human and LM opinions so far, we omitted the ‚Äúrefusal‚Äù option for all question due to its non-ordinal nature.

text.content: Steerability
We now shift our focus from measuring the default aliginment of LM opinions with those of various demographics groups without prompting, to studying their steerability with group-specific prompting

rich_text.plain_text: We now shift our focus from measuring the default aliginment of LM opinions with those of various demographics groups without prompting, to studying their steerability with group-specific prompting

Concretely, we measure steerability as:
where
denotes the LM opinion distribution.
Higher score indicates that the model is better aligned to the opinions of that group

rich_text.plain_text: Higher score indicates that the model is better aligned to the opinions of that group

text.content: Steering doesn‚Äôt solve opinion misalignment
Most LMs do become somewhat more representative of subpopulation post steering.

rich_text.plain_text: Most LMs do become somewhat more representative of subpopulation post steering.

text.content: However, none of the disparities in group opinion alignment of an LM disappear afterr steering.

rich_text.plain_text: However, none of the disparities in group opinion alignment of an LM disappear afterr steering.

text.content: Consistency
Are the views expressed by LMs consistent across the topics?

rich_text.plain_text: Are the views expressed by LMs consistent across the topics?

text.content: Are LMs consistent?
The base model from both providers and RLHF trained text-davinci-003 from OpenAI seem to be most consistent

rich_text.plain_text: The base model from both providers and RLHF trained text-davinci-003 from OpenAI seem to be most consistent

text.content: None of the models are perfectly consistent however.

rich_text.plain_text: None of the models are perfectly consistent however.

Specifically, for a model, we first identify the group it best aligns across topics as

Our metric
is bounnded between 0 and 1, and a higher score implies that the model agrees with the views of same subgroups across all topics.

text.content: Related work
Evaluating LM personas
By leveraging public opinion surveys, we are able to improve our understanding of LM steerability in three ways

rich_text.plain_text: By leveraging public opinion surveys, we are able to improve our understanding of LM steerability in three ways

text.content: Breadth: Both in the range of different topics and steering groups

rich_text.plain_text: Breadth: Both in the range of different topics and steering groups

text.content: Distributional View: Gauging whether LMs can match the spectrum of opinions of a group rather than its modal opinion

rich_text.plain_text: Distributional View: Gauging whether LMs can match the spectrum of opinions of a group rather than its modal opinion

text.content: Measurability: Using metrics grounded in human response distributions

rich_text.plain_text: Measurability: Using metrics grounded in human response distributions

text.content: Human feedback trained models often exhibit a left-leaning, pro-environmental stance.

rich_text.plain_text: Human feedback trained models often exhibit a left-leaning, pro-environmental stance.

text.content: Subjectivity in evaluations
We approach the problem of evaluating opinions expressed by LMs through the use of surveys

rich_text.plain_text: We approach the problem of evaluating opinions expressed by LMs through the use of surveys

text.content: Human-LM Alignment
Asking who are the humans that we are/should be aligning the models to?

rich_text.plain_text: Asking who are the humans that we are/should be aligning the models to?

text.content: Bias, toxicity, and truthfulness
Evaluating LMs on inherently subjective questions taken from Pew research

rich_text.plain_text: Evaluating LMs on inherently subjective questions taken from Pew research

text.content: Conclusions
Limitations
Alignment
We view our metrics as useful ways to understand the behavior of LMs, and not necessarily as benchmarks that should be blindly optimized

rich_text.plain_text: We view our metrics as useful ways to understand the behavior of LMs, and not necessarily as benchmarks that should be blindly optimized

text.content: ATP and surveys
Surveys in general may be sensitive to details such as question specificity, but our conclusions are only valid for the populations to US

rich_text.plain_text: Surveys in general may be sensitive to details such as question specificity, but our conclusions are only valid for the populations to US

text.content: Multiple-choice format
We focus on probing LM behaviors using a multiple-choice prompts, which differs from the open-ended text generation setting in which LMs are being increasingly used.

rich_text.plain_text: We focus on probing LM behaviors using a multiple-choice prompts, which differs from the open-ended text generation setting in which LMs are being increasingly used.
